title: 2 Kings Chapter 19 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Kings chapter 19 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Kings Chapter 19 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Kings Chapter 19.

questions.question: What did King Hezekiah do when he heard the news according to 2 Kings 19:1?
options: Rent his clothes and covered himself with sackcloth
Built a wall around Jerusalem
Sent a letter to the king of Assyria
Went to war immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Rent his clothes and covered himself with sackcloth
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 19:1 states that Hezekiah rent his clothes and covered himself with sackcloth when he heard the news.

questions.question: Who did King Hezekiah send to Isaiah the prophet as mentioned in 2 Kings 19:2?
options: Eliakim, Shebna, and the elders of the priests
The king of Ethiopia
The Assyrian messengers
His sons and soldiers
questions.correctAnswer: Eliakim, Shebna, and the elders of the priests
questions.explanation: Verse 2 says Hezekiah sent Eliakim, Shebna, and the elders of the priests to Isaiah.

questions.question: What message did Hezekiah's servants convey to Isaiah in 2 Kings 19:3?
options: This day is a day of trouble, rebuke, and blasphemy
The Assyrians are retreating
God has given us strength to fight
Peace has been established
questions.correctAnswer: This day is a day of trouble, rebuke, and blasphemy
questions.explanation: Verse 3 states the servants told Isaiah it was a day of trouble, rebuke, and blasphemy.

questions.question: According to 2 Kings 19:6, what did Isaiah tell the servants to say to Hezekiah?
options: Be not afraid of the words which thou hast heard
Prepare for war immediately
Flee to Egypt
Make an alliance with the king of Ethiopia
questions.correctAnswer: Be not afraid of the words which thou hast heard
questions.explanation: Isaiah instructed them to tell Hezekiah not to be afraid of the blasphemous words of the Assyrian servants (verse 6).

questions.question: What did the LORD promise to do to the king of Assyria according to 2 Kings 19:7?
options: Send a blast upon him and cause him to fall by the sword in his own land
Give him great riches
Make him king of all nations
Give him victory over Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Send a blast upon him and cause him to fall by the sword in his own land
questions.explanation: Verse 7 says the LORD will send a blast upon the king of Assyria so that he will return to his land and fall by the sword there.

questions.question: Where was the king of Assyria warring when Rabshakeh returned, as stated in 2 Kings 19:8?
options: Libnah
Lachish
Nineveh
Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Libnah
questions.explanation: Verse 8 mentions Rabshakeh found the king of Assyria warring against Libnah.

questions.question: Who came out to fight against the king of Assyria, mentioned in 2 Kings 19:9?
options: Tirhakah king of Ethiopia
King Hezekiah of Judah
The king of Egypt
The prophet Isaiah
questions.correctAnswer: Tirhakah king of Ethiopia
questions.explanation: Verse 9 states that Tirhakah king of Ethiopia came out to fight against the king of Assyria.

questions.question: What was Hezekiah's reaction after reading the letter from the Assyrian messengers, according to 2 Kings 19:14?
options: He went up into the house of the LORD and spread the letter before the LORD
He immediately destroyed the letter
He sent it to the king of Egypt
He ignored the letter
questions.correctAnswer: He went up into the house of the LORD and spread the letter before the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 14 says Hezekiah read the letter and then went into the house of the LORD and spread it before Him.

questions.question: In Hezekiah's prayer in 2 Kings 19:15, how does he describe God?
options: O LORD God of Israel, which dwellest between the cherubims, thou art the God, even thou alone, of all the kingdoms of the earth
A God who ignores the nations
A god of the Assyrians
A distant and silent deity
questions.correctAnswer: O LORD God of Israel, which dwellest between the cherubims, thou art the God, even thou alone, of all the kingdoms of the earth
questions.explanation: Hezekiah prays and praises God as the one who dwells between the cherubims and is the only true God of all kingdoms (verse 15).

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Kings 19:18, the gods of the nations were destroyed because they were real gods.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 18 explains that the gods were not real gods but the work of men's hands, wood and stone, so they were destroyed.

questions.question: True or False: 2 Kings 19:20 says that God heard Hezekiah's prayer against Sennacherib.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 20 states that the LORD heard Hezekiah's prayer against Sennacherib.

questions.question: What sign did the LORD give according to 2 Kings 19:29?
options: Eating what grows naturally for three years and then sowing and reaping
The sun standing still
A rainbow in the sky
The walls of Jerusalem falling
questions.correctAnswer: Eating what grows naturally for three years and then sowing and reaping
questions.explanation: The LORD said they would eat things that grow of themselves for the first and second years, and in the third year sow and reap (verse 29).

questions.question: According to 2 Kings 19:34, why will God defend Jerusalem?
options: For His own sake and for His servant David's sake
Because of the people's wealth
Because the king paid tribute
Because the Assyrians were weak
questions.correctAnswer: For His own sake and for His servant David's sake
questions.explanation: Verse 34 says God will defend the city for His own sake and for the sake of His servant David.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from 2 Kings 19:35: 'And it came to pass that night, that the angel of the LORD went out, and smote in the camp of the Assyrians an ________.'
options: hundred fourscore and five thousand
thousand
ten thousand
five hundred
questions.correctAnswer: hundred fourscore and five thousand
questions.explanation: Verse 35 specifies the angel smote 185,000 in the Assyrian camp.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Kings 19:37, Sennacherib was killed by his sons while worshipping in the house of Nisroch his god.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 37 describes how Sennacherib was slain by his sons while worshipping in the house of Nisroch.

medium.title: 2 Kings Chapter 19 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Kings Chapter 19 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on 2 Kings 19, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God in times of fear?
options: Trust in God's promises and do not fear the threats of enemies.
Rely solely on your own strength to overcome difficulties.
Ignore threats and avoid prayer, focusing on practical solutions.
Seek alliances with worldly powers instead of God.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God's promises and do not fear the threats of enemies.
questions.explanation: Isaiah encourages Hezekiah not to fear the words of the Assyrian king (2 Kings 19:6-7). Hezekiah’s prayer and God’s assurance show the importance of trusting God rather than fearing enemies (2 Kings 19:15-20).

questions.question: How does Hezekiah’s response to the Assyrian threat teach us about humility and seeking God?
options: He humbled himself, rent his clothes, and prayed earnestly to God for deliverance.
He ignored God and sought help from foreign kings.
He boasted of his own power and military strength.
He tried to negotiate peace through his own wisdom without prayer.
questions.correctAnswer: He humbled himself, rent his clothes, and prayed earnestly to God for deliverance.
questions.explanation: Hezekiah’s immediate response was to humble himself by tearing his clothes and praying to the LORD (2 Kings 19:1, 14-19), demonstrating humility and dependence on God in crisis.

questions.question: What does the chapter teach about prayer as a spiritual discipline in times of crisis?
options: Prayer is a vital way to bring our troubles before God and seek His intervention.
Prayer is only for personal requests and not for communal issues.
Prayer is unnecessary if we have strong armies and resources.
Prayer should be replaced by immediate action without waiting on God.
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer is a vital way to bring our troubles before God and seek His intervention.
questions.explanation: Hezekiah sent messengers to Isaiah and prayed before the LORD, seeking God’s help (2 Kings 19:2-4, 14-19). God’s response through Isaiah shows that prayer invites divine action (2 Kings 19:20-34).

questions.question: What biblical principle about God’s sovereignty and protection can be drawn from 2 Kings 19?
options: God defends and saves His people for His own name's sake and promises.
God’s protection depends solely on human military strength.
God is indifferent to the fate of His people in times of war.
God’s protection must be earned by sacrifices and rituals.
questions.correctAnswer: God defends and saves His people for His own name's sake and promises.
questions.explanation: God declares He will defend Jerusalem for His own sake and David’s sake (2 Kings 19:34). This shows divine sovereignty and faithfulness in protecting His people.

questions.question: When facing opposition, how does this chapter encourage believers to respond with faith?
options: By trusting that God will act on their behalf and defeat the enemy.
By retreating and abandoning their faith under pressure.
By negotiating compromises with worldly powers.
By taking matters into their own hands without seeking God.
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting that God will act on their behalf and defeat the enemy.
questions.explanation: God promises to put a hook in the enemy’s nose and cause him to return (2 Kings 19:28), and Hezekiah’s prayer reflects faith that God will save Judah (2 Kings 19:19).

questions.question: What does Hezekiah’s prayer model teach us about addressing God in prayer?
options: Honoring God's uniqueness and power while honestly presenting our fears and requests.
Praying with boastful claims about our own righteousness.
Ignoring God’s holiness and focusing only on our needs.
Using vague language without acknowledging God’s attributes.
questions.correctAnswer: Honoring God's uniqueness and power while honestly presenting our fears and requests.
questions.explanation: Hezekiah praises God as the unique Creator and Sovereign (2 Kings 19:15), then boldly asks for deliverance (2 Kings 19:16-19), showing reverence and honesty in prayer.

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 19 illustrate the importance of intercession for others in difficult times?
options: Hezekiah intercedes for the remnant of his people, asking God to save them.
Hezekiah only prays for his own safety and ignores others.
Hezekiah refuses to pray because he believes the situation is hopeless.
Hezekiah asks others to pray but does not pray himself.
questions.correctAnswer: Hezekiah intercedes for the remnant of his people, asking God to save them.
questions.explanation: Hezekiah prays for the remnant left in Judah, showing concern for the whole community (2 Kings 19:4, 19). Intercession is a key aspect of faithful prayer.

questions.question: How can this chapter teach us about perseverance through trials?
options: Persevere by continuing to trust God and pray even when the situation looks dire.
Give up when challenges seem overwhelming.
Avoid problems and wait for others to solve them.
Rely only on human wisdom and strength.
questions.correctAnswer: Persevere by continuing to trust God and pray even when the situation looks dire.
questions.explanation: Despite the Assyrian threat, Hezekiah perseveres in prayer and faith, leading to God's deliverance (2 Kings 19:1-19, 35).

questions.question: How does the chapter demonstrate God’s justice in dealing with pride and blasphemy?
options: God humbles Sennacherib, who blasphemed and exalted himself against the Holy One of Israel.
God ignores blasphemy and lets the proud succeed.
God rewards those who boast of their own power.
God encourages pride as a sign of strength.
questions.correctAnswer: God humbles Sennacherib, who blasphemed and exalted himself against the Holy One of Israel.
questions.explanation: God condemns Sennacherib’s blasphemy (2 Kings 19:21-23) and sends the angel to strike down his army (2 Kings 19:35), illustrating divine justice.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Kings 19, Hezekiah’s faith and prayer were instrumental in God's deliverance of Jerusalem.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hezekiah’s prayer was heard by God (2 Kings 19:20), and God’s promise to defend Jerusalem came after Hezekiah’s humble seeking (2 Kings 19:14-19, 34).

questions.question: True or False: The chapter suggests that God’s protection is based on the strength of armies and weapons.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: God explicitly states He will defend Jerusalem and cause the Assyrians to return by the way they came, showing reliance on God’s power, not military might (2 Kings 19:32-33, 35).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Hezekiah prayed to God describing Him as the God who dwells between the __________.
options: cherubims
mountains
temples
rivers
questions.correctAnswer: cherubims
questions.explanation: Hezekiah prayed to the LORD God of Israel, who dwells between the cherubims (2 Kings 19:15), emphasizing God's holy presence and sovereignty.

questions.question: What lesson about evangelism and testimony can we learn from God’s declaration about the remnant in Jerusalem?
options: God’s deliverance is for His glory so that all kingdoms may know He alone is God.
Faith should be kept private and not shared with others.
Physical strength is the main testimony to God’s power.
Evangelism depends on political alliances.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s deliverance is for His glory so that all kingdoms may know He alone is God.
questions.explanation: Hezekiah prayed that all kingdoms would know the LORD alone is God (2 Kings 19:19), and God’s deliverance was a sign to all nations (2 Kings 19:30-31).

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 19 emphasize the importance of integrity and honesty in prayer?
options: Hezekiah honestly presents the threat and his trust in God without pretense.
Hezekiah hides his fears and pretends everything is fine.
Hezekiah blames others and refuses to seek forgiveness.
Hezekiah uses deceitful words to manipulate God.
questions.correctAnswer: Hezekiah honestly presents the threat and his trust in God without pretense.
questions.explanation: Hezekiah openly spreads the letter before God and prays sincerely about the reproach of Sennacherib (2 Kings 19:14-19), showing integrity in his communication with God.

questions.question: What does the chapter teach about God’s care for families and the future generation?
options: God promises a remnant that will take root and bear fruit, ensuring continuity.
God abandons families who face trials.
The future depends solely on human planning.
Families are unimportant in God’s plan.
questions.correctAnswer: God promises a remnant that will take root and bear fruit, ensuring continuity.
questions.explanation: God speaks of the remnant of Judah who shall take root downward and bear fruit upward (2 Kings 19:30), showing His care for the future of His people.

hard.title: 2 Kings Chapter 19 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Kings Chapter 19.

questions.question: What immediate reaction did King Hezekiah have upon hearing the news of the Assyrian threat?
options: He rent his clothes and went into the house of the LORD
He gathered his army immediately
He sent envoys to the king of Assyria
He fled to a neighboring kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: He rent his clothes and went into the house of the LORD
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 19:1 describes how Hezekiah rent his clothes, covered himself with sackcloth, and went into the house of the LORD as a sign of mourning and petition.

questions.question: Who did Hezekiah send to the prophet Isaiah to seek advice and prayer?
options: Eliakim, Shebna, and the elders of the priests
His generals and army captains
The queen mother and his children
Messengers to the king of Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Eliakim, Shebna, and the elders of the priests
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 19:2 states that Hezekiah sent Eliakim, Shebna the scribe, and the elders of the priests to Isaiah to seek God's guidance.

questions.question: In Hezekiah's prayer, how does he describe the LORD God of Israel?
options: The God who dwells between the cherubims and maker of heaven and earth
A distant deity who controls the weather
One of many gods of the earth
A warrior god who fights battles personally
questions.correctAnswer: The God who dwells between the cherubims and maker of heaven and earth
questions.explanation: Hezekiah's prayer in 2 Kings 19:15 acknowledges God as dwelling between the cherubims and being the creator of heaven and earth, emphasizing His unique sovereignty.

questions.question: What literary device is seen in the description of the Assyrian king's arrogance and God's response in verses 22-28?
options: Chiasm
Parable
Allegory
Foreshadowing
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm
questions.explanation: The passage exhibits chiasm, a Hebrew literary structure where ideas are presented and then mirrored in reverse order, emphasizing the conflict between human pride and divine sovereignty (2 Kings 19:22-28).

questions.question: Which phrase best captures the typology of Hezekiah’s prayer in relation to later messianic prayers in the Bible?
options: A plea for divine intervention on behalf of God's people
A call for military conquest and territorial expansion
A vow to punish enemies with sword and fire
An appeal for wealth and prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: A plea for divine intervention on behalf of God's people
questions.explanation: Hezekiah’s prayer (2 Kings 19:19) is a typological foreshadowing of messianic prayers seen in the Psalms and New Testament, calling on God to save His people and reveal His sovereignty.

questions.question: What historical context is highlighted by the mention of cities like Gozan, Haran, and Rezeph in Rabshakeh’s speech?
options: The widespread Assyrian military conquests and destruction of other nations' gods
The alliances formed between Israel and neighboring kingdoms
The economic trade routes controlled by Judah
The cultural exchange between Egypt and Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: The widespread Assyrian military conquests and destruction of other nations' gods
questions.explanation: In 2 Kings 19:12, Rabshakeh refers to cities destroyed by Assyria, emphasizing their military dominance and the futility of trusting other gods compared to Assyria's power.

questions.question: How does the term 'blast' in Isaiah's prophecy (verse 7) function in the narrative?
options: As a divine wind or force causing the Assyrian retreat
As a literal storm sent by natural causes
As a metaphor for political alliances against Assyria
As a symbol of internal Assyrian rebellion
questions.correctAnswer: As a divine wind or force causing the Assyrian retreat
questions.explanation: Isaiah’s prophecy in 2 Kings 19:7 uses 'blast' to signify God’s supernatural intervention causing the Assyrian army to hear rumors and retreat, demonstrating divine sovereignty.

questions.question: True or False: The angel of the LORD killed 185,000 Assyrian soldiers overnight according to this chapter.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 19:35 records that the angel of the LORD smote 185,000 in the Assyrian camp overnight, leading to their defeat by divine means.

questions.question: What is the significance of Hezekiah spreading the Assyrian letter before the LORD in the temple?
options: It symbolizes offering the problem to God for judgment and help
It was a ritual to curse the enemy
It was a political act to shame the Assyrians
It was a way to publicly declare war
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes offering the problem to God for judgment and help
questions.explanation: Hezekiah’s act of spreading the letter before the LORD in 2 Kings 19:14 shows his faith and reliance on God’s justice and intervention.

questions.question: How does the author of 2 Kings use the motif of 'remnant' in this chapter (verses 30-31)?
options: To emphasize God's preservation of a faithful group despite judgment
To describe the complete destruction of Judah
To highlight the political exile of the king
To signify the total conquest by Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: To emphasize God's preservation of a faithful group despite judgment
questions.explanation: Verses 30-31 speak of a 'remnant' of Judah that will survive and bear fruit, emphasizing a theological theme of hope and divine preservation.

questions.question: Which intertextual connection does Hezekiah’s prayer (verse 15-19) have with the Psalms?
options: Both call God the Maker of heaven and earth and defender of His people
Both focus on the creation story in detail
Both emphasize the building of the temple
Both describe the Exodus in vivid terms
questions.correctAnswer: Both call God the Maker of heaven and earth and defender of His people
questions.explanation: Hezekiah’s prayer echoes Psalms such as Psalm 99 and Psalm 46 by invoking God as Creator and protector (2 Kings 19:15-19).

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'I will put my hook in thy nose, and my bridle in thy lips' (verse 28) in the Ancient Near Eastern context?
options: It symbolizes divine control over the arrogant king, like a tamed beast
It refers to a common battle strategy
It is a metaphor for imprisonment in chains
It describes a ritual of peace treaty
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes divine control over the arrogant king, like a tamed beast
questions.explanation: Verse 28 uses imagery familiar in the Ancient Near East where horses and oxen were controlled by a hook and bridle, indicating God’s power to restrain the Assyrian king.

questions.question: What does the fate of Sennacherib at the end of the chapter foreshadow in biblical history?
options: The eventual downfall of oppressive empires by divine justice
The permanent alliance of Assyria and Judah
The rise of Sennacherib as a faithful servant of God
The conquest of Jerusalem by Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: The eventual downfall of oppressive empires by divine justice
questions.explanation: Verses 36-37 show Sennacherib’s assassination, foreshadowing God's judgment against oppressive rulers and reinforcing the theme of divine sovereignty.

questions.question: In the speech of Rabshakeh, what is the theological accusation made against the God of Judah?
options: That He will not deliver Jerusalem from the Assyrian king
That He is the strongest God of all nations
That He has already defeated Assyria
That He is a foreign god imported from Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: That He will not deliver Jerusalem from the Assyrian king
questions.explanation: Rabshakeh mocks the God of Judah by claiming Jerusalem will fall into Assyrian hands (2 Kings 19:10).

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah assures Hezekiah that Sennacherib will enter Jerusalem and conquer it.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah assures Hezekiah that Sennacherib will not enter Jerusalem nor attack it successfully (2 Kings 19:32-33).

theological.title: 2 Kings Chapter 19 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Kings Chapter 19 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: How does Hezekiah respond when he hears the threatening message from the king of Assyria?
options: He rents his clothes and prays to the LORD
He gathers his army and prepares for war
He sends tribute to Assyria
He ignores the message
questions.correctAnswer: He rents his clothes and prays to the LORD
questions.explanation: Hezekiah's response of humility and prayer, tearing his clothes and covering himself with sackcloth, reflects repentance and trust in God (2 Kings 19:1). This aligns with biblical calls to seek God in times of distress (Psalm 34:18; Joel 2:12; Daniel 9:3; James 5:16).

questions.question: Who does Hezekiah send to consult the prophet Isaiah about the Assyrian threat?
options: Eliakim, Shebna, and the elders of the priests
His generals and soldiers
The people of Jerusalem
His sons and advisors
questions.correctAnswer: Eliakim, Shebna, and the elders of the priests
questions.explanation: Hezekiah sends key officials and priests, showing the importance of seeking divine guidance through God’s appointed prophet (2 Kings 19:2). This practice is consistent with seeking prophetic counsel in times of crisis (1 Samuel 9:9; Jeremiah 1:7; Acts 11:27-28; Hebrews 1:1).

questions.question: What is the nature of the message Hezekiah's servants bring to Isaiah?
options: A day of trouble, rebuke, and blasphemy is at hand
A message of peace and alliance
A demand for tribute and surrender
A call for immediate battle
questions.correctAnswer: A day of trouble, rebuke, and blasphemy is at hand
questions.explanation: The servants describe the current crisis as severe, marked by divine rebuke and blasphemy, highlighting human sin and opposition to God’s sovereignty (2 Kings 19:3). This reflects the biblical theme of judgment and the consequences of sin (Isaiah 59:1-2; Romans 1:18; Hebrews 12:6; Revelation 3:19).

questions.question: What does Isaiah tell Hezekiah to do in response to the Assyrian threat?
options: Be not afraid and lift up your prayer for the remnant
Raise an army and fortify the city
Negotiate peace with Assyria
Flee to another city
questions.correctAnswer: Be not afraid and lift up your prayer for the remnant
questions.explanation: Isaiah urges trust in God rather than fear, emphasizing prayer for those who remain faithful, demonstrating God's faithfulness and protection of His people (2 Kings 19:6,4). This echoes biblical calls to trust God in adversity (Psalm 46:1-3; Isaiah 41:10; Philippians 4:6-7; 1 Peter 5:7).

questions.question: How does God promise to deal with the Assyrian king according to Isaiah's prophecy?
options: He will send a blast causing him to hear a rumor and return to his land
He will allow him to conquer Jerusalem
He will give him a plague but not defeat him
He will cause him to become king of another nation
questions.correctAnswer: He will send a blast causing him to hear a rumor and return to his land
questions.explanation: God promises to intervene supernaturally to thwart Assyria’s plans, demonstrating His sovereign control over history (2 Kings 19:7). This divine protection is consistent with God’s deliverance of His people in other biblical events (Exodus 14:21-22; Psalm 91:7; Daniel 6:22; Acts 12:7).

questions.question: What accusation does the Assyrian king make against Hezekiah’s trust in God?
options: That God will not deliver Jerusalem from Assyria
That Hezekiah worships false gods
That Hezekiah is conspiring with Egypt
That Jerusalem's walls are weak
questions.correctAnswer: That God will not deliver Jerusalem from Assyria
questions.explanation: The Assyrian king mocks Hezekiah’s trust, denying God’s power to save (2 Kings 19:10), which represents a common challenge against divine sovereignty and salvation (Psalm 2:1-4; Isaiah 44:6-8; John 3:18; Romans 9:20-21).

questions.question: How does Hezekiah respond after reading the letter from the king of Assyria?
options: He spreads the letter before the LORD and prays
He burns the letter in anger
He sends it back with a defiant message
He hides the letter from the people
questions.correctAnswer: He spreads the letter before the LORD and prays
questions.explanation: Hezekiah’s act of presenting the letter before God signifies complete dependence on divine intervention (2 Kings 19:14-15). This reflects biblical examples of bringing burdens to God in prayer (Psalm 25:1-2; 1 Kings 8:54-55; Philippians 4:6; Hebrews 4:16).

questions.question: In Hezekiah’s prayer, how does he describe God’s uniqueness and sovereignty?
options: God alone is the Creator and ruler of all kingdoms
God is one among many gods
God is limited to the land of Israel
God depends on human strength
questions.correctAnswer: God alone is the Creator and ruler of all kingdoms
questions.explanation: Hezekiah acknowledges God's exclusive deity and creative authority (2 Kings 19:15), consistent with biblical affirmations of monotheism and God’s universal lordship (Deuteronomy 6:4; Isaiah 45:5-7; Colossians 1:16-17; Revelation 4:11).

questions.question: What reason does Hezekiah give for praying for deliverance from Assyria?
options: So all kingdoms may know that God is the LORD alone
To gain wealth and power
To destroy all Assyrians
To prove his own righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: So all kingdoms may know that God is the LORD alone
questions.explanation: Hezekiah’s prayer emphasizes God’s glory and universal recognition as the true God (2 Kings 19:19), reflecting the biblical purpose of salvation as a testimony to God’s sovereignty (Psalm 67:2-3; Isaiah 43:7; Romans 11:36; Revelation 15:4).

questions.question: How does God describe the reaction of Jerusalem, called 'the virgin daughter of Zion,' toward Assyria?
options: She has despised and laughed to scorn the Assyrian king
She is fearful and trembling
She has sought an alliance
She has surrendered
questions.correctAnswer: She has despised and laughed to scorn the Assyrian king
questions.explanation: God portrays Jerusalem as boldly rejecting Assyria’s threats (2 Kings 19:21), symbolizing trust in God’s protection (Psalm 2:4; Isaiah 51:22; Luke 1:48; Revelation 19:7-8).

questions.question: What does God say about the gods of the nations that Assyria has destroyed?
options: They were no gods but works of men's hands
They are more powerful than Israel’s God
They will save those nations
They will retaliate against Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: They were no gods but works of men's hands
questions.explanation: The text denies the divinity of idols, affirming that only the LORD is true God (2 Kings 19:18), consistent with biblical teaching against idolatry and affirming God’s uniqueness (Exodus 20:3-5; Psalm 115:4-8; Isaiah 44:9-20; 1 Corinthians 8:4-6).

questions.question: What sign does God give regarding the agricultural conditions following the Assyrian invasion?
options: There will be food from natural growth for three years
There will be a famine lasting seven years
The land will be barren forever
Crops will fail annually
questions.correctAnswer: There will be food from natural growth for three years
questions.explanation: God promises sustenance through natural produce despite the siege, showing His providential care (2 Kings 19:29). This reflects themes of God’s provision in hardship (Exodus 16:4; 1 Kings 17:14-16; Matthew 6:26-33; Philippians 4:19).

questions.question: What is the ultimate fate of the king of Assyria according to this chapter?
options: He is assassinated by his sons in the temple of his god
He conquers Jerusalem and rules over Judah
He repents and worships the God of Israel
He dies in battle
questions.correctAnswer: He is assassinated by his sons in the temple of his god
questions.explanation: The king’s violent death by his own sons fulfills divine judgment (2 Kings 19:37), consistent with biblical warnings against pride and opposition to God (Psalm 75:7; Proverbs 16:18; Acts 12:23; Revelation 19:20).

questions.question: How does God affirm His defense of Jerusalem?
options: He will save it for His own sake and for David’s sake
He will leave it to human defense
He will destroy it to punish sin
He will allow Assyria to take it
questions.correctAnswer: He will save it for His own sake and for David’s sake
